title: 105_hr4568
content: The Act titled "District of Columbia Retirement Reform Technical Corrections Act of 1998" includes technical and clarifying amendments related to District of Columbia retirement funds. The District of Columbia Retirement Reform Technical Corrections Act of 1998 allows other federal entities to administer the program, permits waiver of recovery of amounts paid in error, and allows the use of the Trust Fund to cover administrative expenses. Expenses related to administering the Trust Fund under the District of Columbia Retirement Reform Technical Corrections Act of 1998 are outlined, including federal benefit payments, administrative expenses, and other specified purposes. The Act also promotes flexibility in program administration. The Trustee may enter subcontracts with approval for services, and the Secretary can determine functions to be performed by them. Reimbursement process for District Government expenses is amended. The Secretary or Trustee may adjust administrative duties as needed. Annual federal payments into the Federal Supplemental Fund are specified. The text chunk involves amendments to a specific Act, including changes to subsections, administrative expenses, and technical corrections. The Secretary is required to pay into the Federal Supplemental Fund for administrative expenses. Technical corrections are made to various sections of the Act. SEC. 3. CLARIFYING TREATMENT OF DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA EMPLOYEES TRANSFERRED TO FEDERAL RETIREMENT SYSTEMS. Eligibility of Nonjudicial Employees of District of Columbia Courts for Medicare and Social Security Benefits is amended to include conforming amendments to the Internal Revenue Code and Social Security Act. Employees Retirement System provided in chapter 84 of title 5, United States Code, after `law of the United States'. Vesting Under Previous District of Columbia Retirement Program includes creditable service for employees whose participation in the District Defined Contribution Plan ceases due to the Balanced Budget Act of 1997, such as continuous service by nonjudicial employees of the District of Columbia courts and service for a successor employer like the Department of Justice or the District of Columbia Offender Supervision, Defender, and Courts Services Agency. SEC. 4. METHODOLOGY FOR DESIGNATING ASSETS OF RETIREMENT FUND. Section 11033 of the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended to include a new subsection regarding the methodology for designating assets of the District Retirement Fund. The Secretary may develop a methodology that considers the fund's value as of the replacement plan adoption date, along with income earned on assets during the period between adoption and designation. The Secretary is not required to determine the value of designated assets as of the adoption date, and the Fund remains entitled to income earned after adoption on retained assets. The Secretary may develop a methodology for designating assets of the District Retirement Fund, including assets for retention and transfer to the Judicial Retirement and Survivors Annuity Fund. The Secretary's methodologies for asset designation under this subsection are final and binding. The Act and its amendments will take effect as if part of the Balanced Budget Act of 1997.
